question

Interface Ledger

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    WarehouseLedger

    public interface Ledger
    A ledger is a big book in which companies keep a record of their commercial transactions, typically one page per day. This interface defines the general characteristics of a ledger that tracks three things: the current day; the current stock level; and the current cash reserve. It allows new transactions to be recorded and the current or earlier day's totals to be inspected. For simplicity, days, stock levels and cash reserves are all represented by type Integer. Days are assumed to be numbered from 1, rather than 0. Your first two tasks in the assignment are to implement this interface as class WarehouseLedger, and to produce a comprehensive unit test suite for it. Constructor: To connect to the provided GUI, your WarehouseLedger class must provide a constructor with the following signature, as well as all the methods below. The current day defaults to 1 when a ledger is constructed. Parameters: Integer initialStock - initial stock level, in items Integer initialCash - initial cash reserve, in dollars Integer wholesaleCostPerItem - how much it costs to buy an item, in dollars Integer retailPricePerItem - how much we get from selling an item, in dollars Integer deliveryCharge - extra cost associated with buying items, in dollars * Throws: WarehouseException - if the stock level, wholesale cost, retail price or delivery charge are negative, or if the wholesale cost is greater than the retail price (but we may trade while insolvent, so no exception is thrown for a negative initial cash reserve!)
    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    CAB302

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void buyItems(java.lang.Integer required)
      Updates the ledger to reflect the purchase of the required number of items at their fixed wholesale cost (provided when the ledger was constructed).
      java.lang.Integer cashAvailable()
      Returns the current cash reserve as recorded in the ledger.
      java.lang.Integer cashAvailable(java.lang.Integer day)
      Returns the cash reserve at the end of the given day, or the current cash reserve if parameter day is today.
      java.lang.Integer currentDay()
      Returns the current day.
      java.lang.Integer inStock()
      Returns the number of items currently in stock as recorded in the ledger.
      java.lang.Integer inStock(java.lang.Integer day)
      Returns the number of items in stock at the end of the given day, or the current number in stock if parameter day is today.
      void nextDay()
      Increments the current day.
      boolean sellItems(java.lang.Integer requested)
      Updates the ledger to reflect the sale of the requested number of items at their fixed retail price (provided when the ledger was constructed).
      java.lang.String toString()
      Returns a human-readable representation of the current state of the ledger.

    • Method Detail

      • nextDay

        void nextDay()
        Increments the current day. (The physical analogy is that it represents turning the page of the ledger.) The previous day's stock level and cash reserve are carried over to the new day.

      • buyItems

        void buyItems(java.lang.Integer required)
       throws WarehouseException
        Updates the ledger to reflect the purchase of the required number of items at their fixed wholesale cost (provided when the ledger was constructed). Both the number of items currently in stock and the current cash reserve are updated. (The cash reserve is allowed to become negative, if necessary, indicating that we have overdrawn our budget.) NB: Apart from the wholesale cost of the items, buying items also incurs a fixed delivery charge (provided when the ledger was constructed), regardless of how many items were bought.
        Parameters:
        required - the number of items being purchased (at wholesale cost)
        Throws:
        WarehouseException - if the number of items to purchase is negative

      • sellItems

        boolean sellItems(java.lang.Integer requested)
           throws WarehouseException
        Updates the ledger to reflect the sale of the requested number of items at their fixed retail price (provided when the ledger was constructed). However, since it's impossible to sell more items than are in stock, the number of items actually sold will be the number requested or the number in stock, whichever is smaller. Both the number of items currently in stock and the current cash reserve are updated.
        Parameters:
        requested - the number of items which have been requested
        Returns:
        true if the order was filled in total, false if there were insufficient items in stock to fill the order
        Throws:
        WarehouseException - if the number of items to be sold is negative

      • currentDay

        java.lang.Integer currentDay()
        Returns the current day. (The physical analogy is that it tells us which page the ledger is opened to.)
        Returns:
        the current day (where days are counted starting at 1)

      • cashAvailable

        java.lang.Integer cashAvailable()
        Returns the current cash reserve as recorded in the ledger. (This value may be negative if the company is trading while insolvent.)
        Returns:
        the current cash reserve (or amount owing), in dollars

      • cashAvailable

        java.lang.Integer cashAvailable(java.lang.Integer day)
                         throws WarehouseException
        Returns the cash reserve at the end of the given day, or the current cash reserve if parameter day is today.
        Parameters:
        day - the day for which we want to look up the cash total
        Returns:
        the amount of cash held in reserve (or owing) at the end of the given day, or the cash currently held if the day of interest is today, in dollars
        Throws:
        WarehouseException - if the given day is less than 1 or greater than the current day

      • inStock

        java.lang.Integer inStock()
        Returns the number of items currently in stock as recorded in the ledger. (The number of items in stock should never be negative.)
        Returns:
        the number of items currently in stock

      • inStock

        java.lang.Integer inStock(java.lang.Integer day)
                   throws WarehouseException
        Returns the number of items in stock at the end of the given day, or the current number in stock if parameter day is today. (The number of items in stock should never be negative.)
        Parameters:
        day - the day for which we want to look up the number of items remaining in stock
        Returns:
        the number of items in stock at the end of the given day, or currently in stock if the day of interest is today
        Throws:
        WarehouseException - if the given day is less than 1 or greater than the current day

      • toString

        java.lang.String toString()
        Returns a human-readable representation of the current state of the ledger. This is a string of the form

        "Day X: Cash reserve = $Y; Items in stock = Z\n"

        where X is the current day, Y is the current cash reserve and Z is the current number of items in stock. (Note: The root class java.lang.Object implements a toString method, which is automatically available to all objects. However, here we require your WarehouseLedger class to override the default toString method with one suitable for use in our warehouse simulation to display the current state of the business.)
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        a human-readable summary of the current state of the ledger
